discourse_list.title: A16z MakerDAO Tokenomics Proposal Two: Aligning Governance Incentives

content.content: Aligning Governance and MKR Holders  Proposal Two: Increasing voter engagement and alignment through a new MKR vesting bonus system for delegates and voters; reduced voting requirements based on enabling more operational flexibility to the Core Units within community-prescribed limits; and creating a new MakerDAO governance dashboard via a community grant. Stanford Political Economy professor Andy Hall wrote an excellent post highlighting some of the key DAO governance challenges throughout the web3 landscape: generating incentive alignment among different stakeholders, maximizing participation, and proactively building an informed electorate. (1) Incentive Alignment: one idea to address incentive alignment among the MakerDAO workforce, MKR delegates, and MKR holders (the actors involved in the two layers of principal-agent relationships @Andrew_Hall referenced) is to reward both regular voters and official delegates with a vesting bonus denominated in MKR tokens based on MakerDAO’s long-term performance and their cumulative activity. This idea bears some similarities to MIP49, which recommended a form of incentive alignment with voters based on staking yields proportional to the financial performance of the protocol, and also the active MKR Compensation MIP, which institutes retroactive vesting rewards. Initially, these tokens could be set aside on MakerDAO’s balance sheet as a reserve vesting pool. Similar to the MKR tokens used by MakerDAO to reward full-time contributors, these tokens could be awarded over 18-36 month intervals based on a publicly-voted formula similar to the delegate compensation model. Top contributors would receive MKR rewards on a quarterly basis, but could only cash out much later based on maintaining performance standards and continued activity. This pilot project could also tie in objective external performance criteria as a metric. Importantly, the vesting pool could be designed to reward smaller holders at significantly higher relative rates versus large holders. Putting a relatively low ceiling on the amount of tokens subject to vesting rewards would prevent large holders from receiving disproportionate rewards at the expense of smaller holders, who this proposal is designed to incentivize. (2) Participation: There are various pros and cons to weigh regarding a possible Curve-inspired “veToken” model application to MakerDAO, as Parafi recently proposed. There could be some benefits to rewarding long-term participants with more voting power; however, @NikKunkel and @monet-supply both raised excellent counterpoints against implementation of the proposal as written. If there were to be a “gbMKR” implementation, the max lock-up could be much shorter (likely one year) and economic incentives may need to be baked in (maybe by incorporating the “gbMKR’’ model into the Secondary Surplus Buffer idea). For now, more data and community debate would be necessary before incorporating a “gbMKR” model, in case the perceived benefits may not outweigh the potential risks. In the meantime, a more near-term focus could be to reduce the number of referendum-style votes by redefining the parameters that core units can openly operate within. For example, MakerDAO already allows core units to complete tasks based on certain polls passing (i.e. if onboarding a new collateral type, the Risk Core Unit conducts a Risk Collateral Assessment). There could be room for more flexibility in specific tasks that shouldn’t require a vote as long as the changes remain within prescribed limits, thereby eliminating any “managerial decision making” on the part of the Core Unit. One possibility would be allowing automatic changes to the System Surplus Buffer (again, within set limits) if it’s tied to other data sources. So if the system’s capital-at-risk increases by $10M, then the System Surplus Buffer automatically increases by $10M as well, and vice versa. Multisigs with enumerated authorizations could also be set up through executive votes. (3) Information and Expertise: one item that could be especially helpful to the community is a new governance dashboard that clearly shows the linear flow for proposals, provides links with details to discussions (the forum is byzantine for experienced users, let alone new ones), and organizes topics in a manner that any newcomer can understand. This dashboard could even directly link to the voting portal. The forums are terrific for in-depth discussions on specific topics, but they are tough to navigate as an organized discourse for governance. The community could create a “Maker Burn”-style site for governance that provides immediate clarity for major proposals, shows progress on governance initiatives, and shares background information for new entrants to quickly onboard. The current governance spreadsheet and MakerDAO governance flowchart are a great start, but there’s room to improve it for everyone. MakerDAO could offer a community grant to the best proposal, or sponsor a competition with retroactive prizes for the top implementation (as voted on by the community). Other DeFi protocols have gone this route with varying levels of success, but given the deep technical expertise embedded in the MakerDAO community, there are probably community members capable of creating a terrific product if the funding arrangement for their contributions is clear. content.content: Porter_Smith:  Importantly, the vesting pool could be designed to reward smaller holders at significantly higher relative rates versus large holders. Putting a relatively low ceiling on the amount of tokens subject to vesting rewards would prevent large holders from receiving disproportionate rewards at the expense of smaller holders, who this proposal is designed to incentivize.   There’s a sybil vulnerability here, but it’s still worth trying to find a mechanism that distributes preferably to smaller holders to aid decentralization.     Porter_Smith:  Multisigs with enumerated authorizations could also be set up through executive votes.   This is an option, though I believe it does require some smart contract work to properly constrain the multi-sig. As far as I understand, the auth system Maker contracts use isn’t terribly flexible, and is just ‘does this address have permissions on this contract’ versus ‘does this address have permissions to change parameter x on this contract.’ There are probably so low-risk areas we could trial this idea, if it is something that people want to proceed with.     Porter_Smith:  (3) Information and Expertise: one item that could be especially helpful to the community is a new governance dashboard   We are working on a few initiatives that address the underlying problem here, though we haven’t yet gone so far as creating an entirely separate site/platform with this intention.     Porter_Smith:  The forums are terrific for in-depth discussions on specific topics, but they are tough to navigate as an organized discourse for governance.   Totally agree, we have something we should be able to show soon that may help with this, though again, it doesn’t meet the desire for a fully curated dashboard.     Porter_Smith:  Other DeFi protocols have gone this route with varying levels of success, but given the deep technical expertise embedded in the MakerDAO community, there are probably community members capable of creating a terrific product if the funding arrangement for their contributions is clear.   If anyone is interested in designing and building such a thing, or just working on the problem in a more general sense, please get in touch with us (GovAlpha).

content.content: I’d like to see MKR holders rewarded for delegation either with a DAI stream or additional MKR. We should consider how large a pool of Recognized Delegates is optimal to support the complexity and growth of the protocol. Then, how might we further “scale” professional governance via increasing token holder interest in and engagement with the responsibilities of delegation, not only via their own direct voting? It is great that we encourage more individuals and teams who can bring a significant contribution of time, skills and specific expertise via Delegate Compensation. Let’s also consider the supply side of MKR engaged in delegation and how to make the proposition more attractive. I have seen comments that suggest dissatisfaction with how/where reasons for votes are communicated. Some have expressed a desire for us to communicate about our own views on vision and strategic direction. There’s probably a role for any new governance dashboard or UI displays to make it much easier for us to communicate and for the community to better understand at a glance the overall point-of-view, biases, vision, policy preferences, etc. about a particular delegate and not just reasons for specific votes. This kind of clarity and transparency should help increase delegated MKR which ensures ample supply for an increasing number of Recognized Delegates to maximize compensation.
